title: Officials seize 342kg of lion bones being illegally exported for medicine
text:
The shipment of lion bones was discovered at an airport in South Africa (Pictures: Getty)

An illegal shipment of lion bones weighing 342kg has been seized at Johannesburg airport in South Africa.

Three people have been arrested after the macabre shipment, destined for Malaysia, was found.

The remains of the big cats were found wrapped in foil and stuffed inside wooden crates.

A spokesperson for the environment agency said: ‘When the shipment was inspected, 12 boxes of lion bones wrapped in aluminium foil and weighing 342kg were discovered.’

These boxes were not properly declared and drew the attention of officials who then arrested three foreign nationals.

Lion bones are used in medicine in the Far East (Picture: Extinction Business) Lion bones are prized in Asia for their supposed medicinal values and to make jewellery.

The lion bone trade is not illegal and the South African government allows a certain quota – 800 skeletons – to be exported each year.

In September last year, Singapore Airlines – the only carrier transporting lion bones from South Africa to Asia – said it was ending the practice.

Supporters claim the bones being sold are just a waste product of the legal hunting industry.

But conservationists say the quotas are routinely flouted and increasing numbers of big cats are being farmed purely for their bones.

Lions are now being reared in captivity and killed for their bones (Picture: Extinction business) Official figures show that in 2017, some 91% of exported skeletons still had their skulls attached.

This means they are unlikely to have been killed by a hunter, who would traditionally take home the head as a sick trophy.

Campaigners say the lion bone trade is fuelling the South African canned hunting industry in which at least 8,000 lions are currently being held in some 300 captive centres.

The ‘cruel trade’ sees cubs hand-reared and used for selfies and walking encounters with unwitting tourists.

They are then transferred to facilities and released into a confined area to be shot dead by a hunter.

The discovery was made at Oliver Tambo International Airport in Johannesburg South Africa (Picture: Getty)

Head of Policy at animal rights charity Born Free, Dr Mark Jones, said: ‘The seizure of a large number of lion bones at Johannesburg airport raises real concerns about the impact of increasing demand for lion bones in the Far East.

‘While international trade on bones and other body parts from wild lions is illegal, demand is being fuelled by the legal export of bones and skeletons derived from the 8,000 or more captive-bred lions in South Africa, under a quota system.

‘Captive-bred lions and other predators are exploited for profit at every stage of their lives.

‘Many of these animals end up being targets for trophy hunters in cruel canned hunts, or being brutally slaughtered so their bones can be exported.

‘The legal trade in bones from captive lions puts ever diminishing wild lion populations at risk, by stimulating demand and incentivising poaching and trafficking.

‘The recent seizure at Johannesburg emphasises just how real the risk is.’

The lion bone trade is legal and the South African government has quotas about how many skeletons can be exported (Picture: Extinction business) The traditional Asian medicine market sees animal bones turned into wines, capsules, gels and balms believed to cure ailments ranging from arthritis to impotence or meningitis.

Often, the lion bones are passed off as those of a tiger – a species also suffering a similar fate, with an estimated 8,000 tigers in farms across Thailand, Laos, Vietnam and China.

A farmer in South Africa can make around £3,000 by selling an adult male skeleton to some of those countries, where the seller in Asia can fetch almost 20 times that.

Born Free has said there is a link between lion bone exports and businesses in South East Asia that have previously been linked to the illegal wildlife trade, including the trafficking of rhino horn.
